::: {#main-content .container role="main"}
::: {#introduction-transforming-sequences .section}
[9.1. ]{.section-number}Introduction: Transforming Sequences[¬∂](#introduction-transforming-sequences "Permalink to this heading"){.headerlink}
==============================================================================================================================================

The sequences that we have used so far have been static: a list of
colors that doesn't change or the characters in a string that stays the
same. The real world is more complicated than that. A list of users for
your social network may need to grow to accommodate new users (or shrink
when users leave your service). The letters in a string may need to be
modified to personalize a message ("Welcome to Wonderland, \<your
name\>"), or to encode a secret message.

The following chapter will detail more of the methods that can be used
to transform lists and strings. Generally, the two methods that can be
used are changing the list object, in place, by mutating it; or by
constructing a new string object using a copy-with-change operation.

::: {#learning-goals .section}
[9.1.1. ]{.section-number}Learning Goals[¬∂](#learning-goals "Permalink to this heading"){.headerlink}
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

-   To understand the concepts of mutable and immutable data types

-   To understand that methods on strings leave the original string
    alone but return a new string

-   To understand that lists are mutable data types and that mutating
    methods on lists return None
:::

::: {#objectives .section}
[9.1.2. ]{.section-number}Objectives[¬∂](#objectives "Permalink to this heading"){.headerlink}
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Demonstrate the correct use of:

-   concatenate

-   index operator

-   substring (slice)

-   search - contains in / not in and index

-   find method

-   append

-   join

-   split

-   string format method
:::
:::
